comments.body: This overlaps with the other overload.

Well it's how it's documented. There isn't any other way to properly type this.

it either takes an object of form `{ b: 512}` that generates a new key. Or the form below which loads a key from string/ buffer or key components with additional arguments about the key. the first form shouldn't take any other arguments.
Maybe the `format` parameter below shouldn't be optional then?

But it is. they are both optional.

If I merge them, then there is no way to be explicit about the difference in both documentation and argument count.

If the developer writes `new NodeRSA({b: 512})` and they get suggestion about the other two arguments they will get confused.

Although, they should read the documentation anyway. Since `KeyComponents` does not include a property with the name `b`, there is no way the second overload gets chosen and the dev sees the correct info.

I'd say if such overloads won't cause problems ( since there is no intersection between the types ), let them be. But if they do (or if it's inconvenient), I'll happily merge the two. Your call üòÅ

So if I pass in exactly one argument, what happens? Does it `Generate new key with length specified.` or `Load key from string/buffer/components.`?
It sounds like if I pass in exactly one argument, only the first overload's documentation is correct, meaning that `format` isn't optional if you're trying to `Load key from string/buffer/components.`.

It would depend on what you pass in first.

if it's `{b: 512}` then it will say new key with no extra arguments.

if it's a buffer object or a string or an object with components (`{n: ..., e: ..., d: ..., ...}`) then it will say load and ask for other two optional arguments too.

Format is optional according to documentations. it will assume some defaults.

P.S. Thanks for helping making this better üëç üëç
